## SECTION 1: Data Link Layer Fundamentals

# What OSI layer number is the Data Link layer? Layer 2
# What is the PDU at Layer 2? Frame

# Five key responsibilities of Data Link layer:
# 1. Physical addressing using MAC addresses
# 2. Framing - encapsulating network layer packets
# 3. Error detection using CRC
# 4. Media access control
# 5. Flow control - preventing receiver overflow


## SECTION 2: Data Link Sublayers

# Upper Sublayer:
# Name: LLC (Logical Link Control)
# IEEE Standard: 802.2
# Functions:
# - Interface between Network layer and MAC sublayer
# - Flow control between sender and receiver
# - Error control and retransmission
# - Multiplexing Network layer protocols

# Lower Sublayer:
# Name: MAC (Media Access Control)
# IEEE Standards: 802.3 (Ethernet), 802.11 (Wi-Fi), 802.5 (Token Ring)
# Functions:
# - Frame assembly/disassembly
# - Physical addressing with MAC addresses
# - Media access management (CSMA/CD, CSMA/CA)
# - Error detection using FCS (Frame Check Sequence)


## SECTION 3: MAC Address Structure

# A MAC address is 48 bits long
# Displayed in hexadecimal format

# Standard notation example: 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E

# Alternative notations:
# Dash-separated: 00-1A-2B-3C-4D-5E
# Cisco format: 001A.2B3C.4D5E

# First 24 bits (3 bytes): OUI (Organizationally Unique Identifier)
# Purpose: Identifies manufacturer
# Assigned by: IEEE

# Last 24 bits (3 bytes): Device Identifier
# Purpose: Unique device number assigned by manufacturer
# Assigned by: Manufacturer
# Should be unique: Worldwide (yes)


## SECTION 4: Manufacturer OUI Examples

# Match the OUI to manufacturer:
# 00:50:56 = VMware
# 00:0C:29 = VMware
# 08:00:27 = Oracle VirtualBox
# 00:1B:63 = Apple
# 00:15:5D = Microsoft Hyper-V


## SECTION 5: Special MAC Addresses

# Broadcast MAC address: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
# Purpose: Send to all devices on network

# IPv4 Multicast MAC address pattern: 01:00:5E:xx:xx:xx
# Purpose: Send to group of devices

# IPv6 Multicast MAC address pattern: 33:33:xx:xx:xx:xx

# Locally Administered MAC address:
# Indicator: Second character is 2, 6, A, or E
# Meaning: Modified by administrator


## SECTION 6: MAC Address Types

# Unicast:
# Least significant bit of first byte = 0
# Sent to: Single destination
# Example: 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E (unicast? Yes)

# Multicast:
# Least significant bit of first byte = 1
# Sent to: Group of devices
# Example: 01:00:5E:00:00:01 (multicast? Yes)

# Broadcast:
# All bits set to: 1
# Sent to: All devices on local network
# Address: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
# Can source MAC be broadcast? No (must always be unicast)


## SECTION 7: Ethernet Frame Structure - Complete the Frame

# Ethernet II Frame Fields (in order):
# 1. Preamble (7 bytes)
# 2. SFD (1 byte) - Start Frame Delimiter
# 3. Destination MAC Address (6 bytes)
# 4. Source MAC Address (6 bytes)
# 5. Type/Length Field (2 bytes)
# 6. Payload (46-1500 bytes)
# 7. FCS (4 bytes) - Frame Check Sequence


## SECTION 8: Preamble and SFD

# Preamble:
# Size: 7 bytes
# Pattern: Alternating 1s and 0s (10101010...)
# Purpose: Synchronization between sender and receiver
# Considered part of frame by tools? No

# Start Frame Delimiter (SFD):
# Size: 1 byte
# Pattern: 10101011
# Purpose: Marks end of preamble and start of frame


## SECTION 9: Frame Field Details

# Destination MAC Address:
# Size: 6 bytes
# Can be: Unicast, multicast, or broadcast

# Source MAC Address:
# Size: 6 bytes
# Must always be: Unicast
# Can NEVER be: Broadcast or multicast

# Type/Length Field:
# Size: 2 bytes
# If value >= 1536: Indicates Type (protocol type)
# Examples:
# - 0x0800 = IPv4
# - 0x0806 = ARP
# - 0x86DD = IPv6
# If value <= 1500: Indicates Payload size (IEEE 802.3)


## SECTION 10: Payload and FCS

# Payload:
# Minimum size: 46 bytes
# Maximum size: 1500 bytes (MTU - Maximum Transmission Unit)
# If payload < 46 bytes: Frame is padded
# Contains: Data from Network layer

# Frame Check Sequence (FCS):
# Size: 4 bytes
# Method: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check)
# Calculated by: Sender
# Verified by: Receiver
# If check fails: Frame is discarded


## SECTION 11: Frame Sizes

# Minimum Ethernet frame size: 64 bytes (including headers, excluding preamble/SFD)
# Maximum standard Ethernet frame size: 1518 bytes
# Jumbo frames: Up to 9000 bytes
# Jumbo frames use case: Data centers (standard or non-standard: Non-standard)


## SECTION 12: Hub vs Switch Comparison

# Hub (Layer 1) characteristics:
# Intelligence: None
# Forwarding method: Broadcasts to all ports
# Collisions: Yes
# Duplex: Half-duplex
# Bandwidth: Shared among all ports
# Performance: Poor
# Status: Obsolete

# Switch (Layer 2) characteristics:
# Intelligence: Uses MAC address table
# Forwarding method: Sends only to destination
# Collisions: No
# Duplex: Full-duplex
# Bandwidth: Dedicated per port
# Performance: Excellent
# Status: Standard


## SECTION 13: Switch Operation - Learning Process

# Step 1 - Learning:
# Switch receives frame on port (any port)
# Reads source MAC address
# Records "MAC address → Port" in MAC address table
# Sets aging timer (typically 300 seconds)

# Step 2 - Forwarding:
# Switch reads destination MAC address
# Looks up MAC in address table
# Forwards frame only to destination port
# If MAC not found: Floods to all ports except source

# Step 3 - Filtering:
# Switch knows source and destination on same port
# Action: Drops frame (no forwarding needed)

# Step 4 - Aging:
# Entries removed after timeout (default 300 seconds)
# Purpose: Prevents stale entries from outdated devices


## SECTION 14: MAC Address Table Example

# Question 1: How many devices on Port 1? 2
# Question 2: Which entry will age out first? Port 1, MAC 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:02 (age 120, closest to 300)
# Question 3: If frame arrives destined for 00:1A:2B:3C:4D:01, send to Port 1
# Question 4: If frame arrives from new MAC 99:88:77:66:55:44 on Port 4, switch will learn and add to table


## SECTION 15: Switch Flooding

# When does flooding occur? (List 3 scenarios)
# 1. Destination MAC not in table
# 2. Broadcast frame (FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF)
# 3. Multicast frame (depends on configuration)

# What is flooding?
# Action: Sending frame to all ports except source

# Purpose:
# Necessary for: Initial learning and broadcasts

# Problem:
# Can cause: Performance issues if excessive


## SECTION 16: Switching Methods

# Store-and-Forward:
# Process:
# 1. Receive entire frame
# 2. Check FCS for errors
# 3. Look up destination MAC
# 4. Forward frame
# Advantages: Error checking (drops bad frames), most reliable
# Disadvantages: Higher latency
# Used by: Most modern switches

# Cut-Through:
# Process:
# 1. Read destination MAC (first 14 bytes)
# 2. Immediately start forwarding
# 3. No error checking
# Advantages: Lower latency, faster forwarding
# Disadvantages: Forwards bad frames, can propagate errors
# Variants:
# - Fast-forward: Forwards immediately after reading dest MAC
# - Fragment-free: Waits for first 64 bytes (collision window)


## SECTION 17: Real-World Scenario 1 - Switch Learning

# Question 1: What does switch learn from this frame?
# Answer: MAC AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA is on Port 1

# Question 2: Does switch know where PC-B is?
# Answer: No

# Question 3: What does switch do with frame?
# Answer: Floods to all ports except Port 1

# Question 4: PC-B receives frame and replies. What does switch learn?
# Answer: MAC BB:BB:BB:BB:BB:BB is on Port 2

# Question 5: Now PC-A sends another frame to PC-B. What happens?

## SECTION 18: Real-World Scenario 2 - Broadcast Frame

# Question 1: What type of MAC address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF?
# Answer: Broadcast

# Question 2: What does switch do with this frame?
# Answer: Floods to all ports except Port 5

# Question 3: How many devices receive this frame?
# Answer: 23 (24 total ports minus 1 source)

# Question 4: This creates a broadcast domain

# Question 5: How can you reduce broadcast domains?
# Answer: Use VLANs (Virtual LANs)


## SECTION 19: Real-World Scenario 3 - Aging Timer

# Question 1: What happens to old entry after 300 seconds?
# Answer: Entry is removed from MAC table

# Question 2: Device plugged into Port 12 sends frame. What does switch learn?
# Answer: MAC 00:11:22:33:44:55 is now on Port 12

# Question 3: Why is aging important?
# Answer: Prevents stale entries, keeps table current

# Question 4: What happens if device is silent for 300+ seconds?
# Answer: Entry ages out, next frame destined for device causes flooding


## SECTION 20: Real-World Scenario 4 - Hub vs Switch Performance

# Scenario A: Using Hub
# Total bandwidth: 100 Mbps (shared among all)
# Each computer gets approximately: 12.5 Mbps (100/8)
# Collisions: Yes
# Performance: Poor

# Scenario B: Using Switch
# Bandwidth per port: 100 Mbps (dedicated)
# Each computer gets: Full 100 Mbps
# Collisions: No
# Performance: Excellent

# Conclusion: Switch provides better performance


## SECTION 21: Store-and-Forward vs Cut-Through

# Switch A (Store-and-Forward):
# Must receive: Entire frame before forwarding
# Checks: FCS for errors
# Latency: Higher
# Bad frames: Drops
# Reliability: More

# Switch B (Cut-Through, Fast-Forward):
# Reads only: First 14 bytes (destination MAC)
# Checks: None (no error checking)
# Latency: Lower
# Bad frames: Forwards
# Problem: Can propagate errors throughout network

# Which method do modern switches typically use?
# Answer: Store-and-Forward


## SECTION 22: Fragment-Free Switching

# Waits for first 64 bytes
# Why 64 bytes? Covers collision window
# Ensures: No collision fragments
# Still faster than: Store-and-Forward
# Still no: Full error checking


## SECTION 23: Understanding Collisions

# Collisions occur in Half-duplex environments

# Half-Duplex:
# Can send or receive: One at a time (not both)
# Device type: Hub
# Collision detection: CSMA/CD (CSMA/CD protocol)
# Performance: Poor

# Full-Duplex:
# Can send and receive: Simultaneously
# Device type: Switch
# Collisions: No
# Performance: Excellent

# Modern Ethernet uses: Full-duplex with switches


## SECTION 24: Frame Error Detection

# If FCS is valid:
# Action: Accept frame

# If FCS is invalid:
# Action: Discard frame
# Does receiver request retransmission? No (Layer 2 doesn't handle retransmission)
# Layer responsible for retransmission: Layer 4 (Transport layer)

# CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check):
# Type of error detection: Mathematical checksum
# Calculated on: Entire frame contents
# Can detect: Single bit errors, burst errors, most errors
# Can correct errors? No (only detect)


## SECTION 25: Minimum Frame Size - Why 64 Bytes?

# Minimum frame size: 64 bytes
# Related to: Collision detection

# In CSMA/CD (Collision Detection):
# Device must still be transmitting when collision detected
# On 10 Mbps Ethernet with 100m cable:
# Minimum frame ensures: Sender detects collisions
# If frame too small: Collision might occur after transmission ends, causing undetected collision

# Padding:
# If payload < 46 bytes: Add padding to reach minimum
# Padding adds: 0s bytes to reach 46-byte payload
# Total frame with padding: Still meets 64 byte minimum


## SECTION 26: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit)

# Standard Ethernet MTU: 1500 bytes
# Refers to: Maximum payload size
# Does NOT include: Ethernet headers

# If Network layer packet > 1500 bytes:
# Action: Packet must be fragmented
# This is called: Fragmentation
# Performed by: Layer 3 (Network layer)

# Jumbo Frames:
# Size: Up to 9000 bytes
# Advantage: Fewer frames for large data, less overhead
# Disadvantage: Non-standard, must be supported by all devices
# Use case: High-speed data centers, storage networks

## SECTION 29: VLAN Fundamentals

# VLAN stands for: Virtual Local Area Network

# What is a VLAN?
# Answer: A logical grouping of devices on different physical network segments, as if they were on the same LAN

# Five benefits of VLANs:
# 1. Segmentation: Separate broadcast domains
# 2. Security: Isolate sensitive traffic
# 3. Performance: Reduce broadcast traffic
# 4. Flexibility: Group users logically, not physically
# 5. Cost savings: No need for multiple switches


## SECTION 30: VLAN Types

# Default VLAN:
# VLAN number: 1
# All ports belong to: VLAN 1 by default
# Can be deleted? No
# Best practice: Don't use for user traffic

# Data VLAN:
# Purpose: User traffic
# Most common type? Yes

# Voice VLAN:
# Dedicated to: VoIP traffic
# Priority: QoS priority
# Can coexist with data VLAN on same port? Yes

# Management VLAN:
# Purpose: Switch management traffic
# Should be separate from: User VLANs
# Security reason: Isolate administrative access

# Native VLAN:
# Used for: Untagged traffic on trunk ports
# Default native VLAN: 1
# Security risk if: Not changed
# Best practice: Change native VLAN to unused VLAN number


## SECTION 31: IEEE 802.1Q VLAN Tagging

# Standard: IEEE 802.1Q
# Tag size: 4 bytes
# Inserted: After source MAC address
# Contains: VLAN ID (range: 1 to 4094)

# Tag Structure:
# TPID (Tag Protocol Identifier):
# Size: 2 bytes
# Value: 0x8100 (indicates 802.1Q)

# PCP (Priority Code Point):
# Size: 3 bits
# Purpose: QoS (Quality of Service)

# DEI (Drop Eligible Indicator):
# Size: 1 bit
# Purpose: Indicates if frame can be dropped during congestion

# VID (VLAN Identifier):
# Size: 12 bits
# Range: 1 to 4094 (0 and 4095 reserved)
# Total possible VLANs: 4094


## SECTION 32: Access vs Trunk Ports

# Access Port:
# Connects to: End devices (PC, printer, server)
# Belongs to: Single VLAN
# Traffic type: Untagged
# Configuration command: switchport mode access
# Example devices: PC, printer, server

# Trunk Port:
# Connects: Between switches
# Carries: Multiple VLANs
# Traffic type: Tagged
# Tagging standard: 802.1Q
# Configuration command: switchport mode trunk
# Purpose: Allow multiple VLANs to traverse between switches


## SECTION 33: VLAN Benefits Example

# Without VLANs on a switch:
# Broadcast domain: One for all devices
# Security: Sales can see HR traffic
# Performance: Excessive broadcasts affect all

# With VLANs:
# Sales PCs → VLAN 10
# HR PCs → VLAN 20
# IT PCs → VLAN 30
# Result:
# - Separate broadcast domains
# - Improved security
# - Better performance


## SECTION 34: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) - The Problem

# What problem does STP solve?
# Answer: Prevents Layer 2 loops in networks with redundant paths

# Without STP in redundant topology:
# Problem 1: Broadcast storms (frames loop infinitely)
# Problem 2: MAC address table instability
# Problem 3: Network becomes unusable in seconds

# Example topology:
# Three switches connected in triangle
# Without STP: Broadcast frame loops forever
# Result: Broadcast storm


## SECTION 35: How STP Works - Four Steps

# Step 1: Elect Root Bridge
# Selection: Switch with lowest Bridge ID
# Bridge ID = Priority (default 32768) + MAC address
# Role: Reference point for spanning tree

# Step 2: Determine Root Ports
# One per: Each non-root switch
# Selection: Port closest to root
# Based on: Path cost

# Step 3: Determine Designated Ports
# One per: Each network segment
# Selection: Port closest to root on each link

# Step 4: Block Remaining Ports
# Purpose: Prevents loops
# Status: Can transition to forwarding if link fails
# This provides: Redundancy


## SECTION 36: STP Port States

# Blocking:
# Forwards data? No
# Learns MACs? No
# Duration: 20 seconds (max age)
# Purpose: Prevents loops

# Listening:
# Forwards data? No
# Learns MACs? No
# Duration: 15 seconds
# Purpose: Listening for BPDUs

# Learning:
# Forwards data? No
# Learns MACs? Yes
# Duration: 15 seconds
# Purpose: Building MAC table

# Forwarding:
# Forwards data? Yes
# Learns MACs? Yes
# Duration: Indefinite
# Purpose: Normal operation

# Disabled:
# Forwards data? No
# Learns MACs? No
# Trigger: Manual shutdown

# Total convergence time: ~50 seconds (30 sec transition + 20 sec max age)


## SECTION 37: STP Variants

# CST (Common Spanning Tree):
# Standard: IEEE 802.1D
# Convergence: Slow (50 seconds)
# Spanning trees: One for all VLANs
# Status: Original/legacy

# PVST+ (Per-VLAN Spanning Tree Plus):
# Vendor: Cisco proprietary
# Spanning trees: Separate per VLAN
# Advantage: Better load balancing

# RSTP (Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol):
# Standard: IEEE 802.1w
# Convergence: Fast (< 6 seconds)
# Backward compatible with: STP
# Status: Most common today

# MSTP (Multiple Spanning Tree Protocol):
# Standard: IEEE 802.1s
# Method: Groups VLANs into instances
# Advantage: Reduces overhead vs PVST+


## SECTION 38: PortFast Feature

# PortFast function: Port transitions immediately to forwarding state
# Bypasses: Listening and learning states
# Use case: Access ports connected to end devices
# Configuration: Manual enable on access ports

# WARNING - Never enable PortFast on:
# Answer: Ports connected to switches
# Reason: Would cause loops (bypasses STP blocking)
# Result: Broadcast storm

# When to use PortFast:
# Port connects to: PC, printer, server, phone
# Benefit: Immediate connectivity (no 30-second wait)


## SECTION 39: Layer 2 vs Layer 3 Switches

# Layer 2 Switch:
# Forwards based on: MAC addresses
# Routing between VLANs? No
# Broadcast domains: Single (unless VLANs configured)
# Cost: Lower
# Configuration: Simple

# Layer 3 Switch:
# Forwards based on: IP addresses
# Function: Combines switch and router functions
# Can route between VLANs? Yes
# Cost: Higher
# Performance: Faster than separate router
# Common in: Modern networks


## SECTION 40: Common Layer 2 Issues

# Issue 1: Broadcast Storms
# Cause: Layer 2 loops, missing STP
# Symptom: Network completely unusable, high CPU on switches
# Solution: Enable STP/RSTP, fix cabling loops

# Issue 2: MAC Address Table Overflow
# Cause: Attack flooding table with fake MACs
# Symptom: Switch becomes hub (floods everything)
# Solution: Port security, limit MAC addresses per port

# Issue 3: VLAN Hopping
# Cause: Misconfigured trunk ports, native VLAN issues
# Symptom: Unauthorized access to other VLANs
# Solution: Change native VLAN, disable unused ports, proper trunk configuration

# Issue 4: Duplex Mismatch
# Cause: One side auto, other side hardcoded
# Symptom: Slow performance, late collisions
# Solution: Match duplex settings (both auto or both fixed)


## SECTION 41: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol)

# ARP purpose: Resolves IP address to MAC address
# Layer: Operates at Layer 2
# Process:
# 1. Device broadcasts "Who has IP x.x.x.x?"
# 2. Target responds with MAC address
# 3. Results cached in ARP table

# ARP Request:
# Type: Broadcast (sent to FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF)
# Contains: Sender's IP and MAC, target's IP

# ARP Reply:
# Type: Unicast (sent to specific MAC)
# Contains: Target's IP and MAC

# Ethernet Type field for ARP: 0x0806


## SECTION 42: Discovery Protocols

# CDP (Cisco Discovery Protocol):
# Vendor: Cisco proprietary
# Purpose: Share device information between neighbors
# Used for: Network mapping
# Security concern: Can reveal topology

# LLDP (Link Layer Discovery Protocol):
# Standard: IEEE 802.1AB
# Type: Vendor-neutral
# Purpose: Same as CDP but open standard
# Advantage: Works with multiple vendors

# Information shared:
# - Device hostname
# - Software version
# - Port identifier
# - VLAN information
# - Device capabilities


## SECTION 43: PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol)

# PPP is a Layer 2 WAN protocol
# Use cases: Dial-up, DSL connections

# Authentication methods:
# PAP (Password Authentication Protocol): Clear text (insecure)
# CHAP (Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol): Hashed (more secure)

# PPP advantages:
# - Error detection
# - Authentication
# - Link quality monitoring
# - Multi-protocol support

# Question 1: What is this attack called?
# Answer: VLAN hopping

# Question 2: How to prevent?
# 1. Change native VLAN to unused number
# 2. Disable unused ports
# 3. Use explicit tagging on all trunk ports

# Question 3: Why is VLAN 1 dangerous?
# Answer: Default for all VLANs, common attack target


## SECTION 49: Real-World Scenario 10 - MAC Table Overflow Attack

# Question 1: What happens to MAC table?
# Answer: Table fills with fake entries

# Question 2: When table is full, switch behavior?
# Answer: Switch acts like hub (floods all frames)

# Question 3: Attacker can now?
# Answer: Sniff other users' traffic

# Question 4: This attack is called?
# Answer: MAC flooding attack or CAM table overflow

# Question 5: Prevention?
# Answer: Port security (limit MAC addresses per port)


## SECTION 50: ARP Process Example

# Step 1: PC-A checks ARP cache
# Step 2: MAC not found, sends ARP request
# Step 3: ARP request destination MAC: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
# Step 4: ARP request asks: "Who has 192.168.1.20?"
# Step 5: PC-B receives, sends ARP reply
# Step 6: ARP reply destination MAC: AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA
# Step 7: PC-A learns: 192.168.1.20 = BB:BB:BB:BB:BB:BB
# Step 8: Entry saved in ARP table
# Step 9: Future frames to PC-B use: Cached MAC address

# PPP: Point-to-Point WAN protocol

# Question 1: Five critical Layer 2 functions:
# 1. Physical addressing (MAC addresses)
# 2. Framing (encapsulation)
# 3. Error detection (FCS/CRC)
# 4. Media access control
# 5. Flow control

# Question 2: Why is Data Link Layer crucial?
# Answer: Bridges Physical layer (bits) and Network layer (packets), enables reliable local network communication

# Question 3: Difference between switch and router?
# Answer: Switch = Layer 2 (MAC addresses), Router = Layer 3 (IP addresses)

# Question 4: When would you use VLANs?
# Answer: To separate broadcast domains, improve security, segment traffic logically without multiple switches

# Question 5: Why is STP/RSTP critical in redundant networks?
# Answer: Prevents broadcast storms and loops while maintaining redundancy for failover

# Question 6: Most important Layer 2 security concerns:
# 1. MAC flooding attacks (port security)
# 2. VLAN hopping (change native VLAN, disable unused ports)
# 3. Broadcast storms (enable STP/RSTP)

# Question 7: What happens if Frame Check Sequence (FCS) fails?
# Answer: Frame is discarded, no retransmission at Layer 2 (handled by Layer 4 if needed)

# Question 8: Three things you'd check when troubleshooting Layer 2:
# 1. MAC address table (show mac address-table)
# 2. VLAN configuration (show vlan)
# 3. STP status (show spanning-tree)


# =============================================
# KEY CONCEPTS - DATA LINK LAYER COMPLETE
# =============================================

# LAYER 2 FUNDAMENTALS:
# - Layer 2 uses frames (MAC addresses)
# - Two sublayers: LLC (802.2) and MAC (802.3)
# - Functions: addressing, framing, error detection, media access, flow control

# MAC ADDRESSES:
# - 48 bits, hexadecimal (XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX)
# - OUI (24 bits) = manufacturer, Device ID (24 bits) = unique
# - Broadcast: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF
# - Source MAC always unicast

# ETHERNET FRAMES:
# - Minimum 64 bytes, maximum 1518 bytes (standard)
# - Preamble(7B) + SFD(1B) + Dest(6B) + Src(6B) + Type(2B) + Payload(46-1500B) + FCS(4B)
# - FCS = CRC error detection
# - Type field: 0x0800=IPv4, 0x0806=ARP, 0x86DD=IPv6

# SWITCHES:
# - Layer 2 devices, MAC address table, full-duplex, dedicated bandwidth
# - Learning: source MAC → port
# - Forwarding: destination MAC → port (or flood if unknown)
# - Aging: 300 seconds default
# - Store-and-forward most common (checks FCS)

# VLANs:
# - Logical segmentation, separate broadcast domains
# - 802.1Q tagging (4 bytes), VID 1-4094
# - Access port: single VLAN, untagged
# - Trunk port: multiple VLANs, tagged
# - Native VLAN: untagged on trunk, change from default 1

# STP/RSTP:
# - Prevents loops in redundant topologies
# - Root bridge election, root ports, designated ports, blocked ports
# - STP: 50 seconds convergence
# - RSTP: < 6 seconds convergence (modern standard)
# - PortFast: ONLY on access ports to end devices, NEVER to switches

# LAYER 2 ISSUES:
# - Broadcast storms (enable STP)
# - MAC flooding (port security)
# - VLAN hopping (change native VLAN)
# - Duplex mismatch (match settings)

# KEY PROTOCOLS:
# - ARP: IP to MAC resolution
# - CDP/LLDP: Device discovery
# - STP/RSTP: Loop prevention
# - PPP: Point-to-point WAN
hints: Data Link Layer is Layer 2, uses frames as PDU, bridges Physical and Network layers
Two sublayers: LLC (802.2, upper) handles flow control; MAC (802.3/802.11, lower) handles physical addressing
MAC address: 48 bits (6 bytes), hexadecimal notation, format XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX
First 24 bits = OUI (manufacturer), last 24 bits = unique device identifier
Broadcast MAC: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF sends to all devices; source MAC is ALWAYS unicast
Ethernet frame: Preamble(7B) + SFD(1B) + Dest MAC(6B) + Src MAC(6B) + Type(2B) + Payload(46-1500B) + FCS(4B)
Minimum frame: 64 bytes total; Maximum standard frame: 1518 bytes; Jumbo frames: 9000 bytes
Hub (Layer 1): broadcasts to all, shared bandwidth, collisions, obsolete
Switch (Layer 2): uses MAC table, dedicated bandwidth per port, no collisions, full-duplex
Switch learning: reads source MAC, records port, sets 300-second aging timer
Switch forwarding: reads destination MAC, looks up in table, forwards to specific port or floods if unknown
Flooding occurs when: destination MAC unknown, broadcast frame (FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF), or multicast
Store-and-Forward: receives entire frame, checks FCS, most reliable, higher latency (modern standard)
Cut-Through: reads first 14 bytes (dest MAC), forwards immediately, lower latency, no error checking
Fragment-Free switching: waits for 64 bytes (collision window), hybrid approach
FCS (Frame Check Sequence): 4-byte CRC calculated by sender, verified by receiver, discards if invalid
Type field >= 1536 = protocol (0x0800=IPv4, 0x0806=ARP, 0x86DD=IPv6); <= 1500 = payload length
MTU = Maximum Transmission Unit = 1500 bytes payload (not including headers)
Minimum 64 bytes ensures collision detection in CSMA/CD, padding added if payload < 46 bytes
MAC table aging: default 300 seconds, prevents stale entries, device mobility handled automatically
Half-duplex (hub): send OR receive, collisions possible; Full-duplex (switch): send AND receive simultaneously
ARP (Type 0x0806) uses broadcast to resolve IP to MAC address
VLAN = Virtual Local Area Network, separates broadcast domains logically
802.1Q VLAN tagging: 4 bytes inserted after source MAC, VID range 1-4094
Access port: single VLAN, untagged; Trunk port: multiple VLANs, tagged with 802.1Q
Default VLAN is VLAN 1, cannot be deleted, best practice: don't use for user traffic
Native VLAN: untagged traffic on trunk, default VLAN 1, security risk if not changed
STP prevents broadcast storms by blocking redundant ports while maintaining failover capability
STP convergence: 50 seconds (802.1D); RSTP convergence: < 6 seconds (802.1w) - modern standard
PortFast: bypasses STP states for immediate connectivity, ONLY use on end device ports, NEVER on switch ports
Root bridge: lowest Bridge ID (priority 32768 + MAC), reference point for spanning tree
STP port states: Blocking(20s) → Listening(15s) → Learning(15s) → Forwarding(indefinite)
Layer 3 switch: routes between VLANs using IP addresses, combines switch and router functions
Broadcast storm symptoms: network unusable, 100% CPU on switches, caused by Layer 2 loops without STP
MAC flooding attack: fills MAC table with fake entries, switch becomes hub, prevention: port security
VLAN hopping: exploits native VLAN and trunk misconfiguration, prevention: change native VLAN, disable unused ports
ARP resolves IP to MAC: broadcasts 'Who has IP?', target replies with MAC, cached in ARP table
CDP (Cisco proprietary) vs LLDP (IEEE 802.1AB vendor-neutral): device discovery protocols
Duplex mismatch: one side auto, other hardcoded, causes slow performance and late collisions
